Vulnerabilities.Title: zlib: heap-based buffer over-read and overflow in inflate in inflate.c
Vulnerabilities.Description: zlib is a library implementing the deflate compression method found in gzip and PKZIP. In zlib before 1.2.12, the inflate code, which decompress deflate data, has a heap-based buffer over-read or buffer overflow. This occurs in the function inflate() in inflate.c when processing some types of invalid deflate data.

Vulnerabilities.Title: SM2 Decryption Buffer Overflow
Vulnerabilities.Description:
In order to decrypt SM2 encrypted data an application is expected to call the EVP_PKEY_decrypt() function. Typically an application will call this function twice. The first time, on entry, the "out" parameter will be NULL and the "outlen" parameter will be a pointer to a size_t containing the value 0. This will cause the function to place the required buffer size in "outlen" and it will return the value 1. The application can then allocate a sufficiently sized buffer and call EVP_PKEY_decrypt() again, but this time passing a non-NULL value for the "out" parameter.

A bug exists in the implementation of the SM2 decryption code. After the first call to EVP_PKEY_decrypt(), the "outlen" parameter is incremented by 1. When the application calls EVP_PKEY_decrypt() the second time an attempt is made to write bytes beyond the end of the allocated buffer.

This issue only affects applications that make use of the built-in SM2 encryption in OpenSSL. This feature is not enabled by default and has to be specifically enabled via a compile time option. In most cases it is unlikely that an application would use this feature unintentionally. The location of the buffer overrun is likely to be at a different address for each run of the application which reduces the likelihood of this bug having a significant security impact in practice. However it could cause applications using this functionality to crash.

The OpenSSL 1.1.1 FIPS provider also includes SM2 decryption. However the above issue does not affect it because additional validation steps are performed in the FIPS provider.

Vulnerabilities.Title: HSTS bypass via IDN
Vulnerabilities.Description: When curl's HSTS support is enabled, it maintains a cache file that stores entries for HSTS hosts. The file parser for this file implicitly assumes that each line in the file is at most 255 characters long. If a longer line is provided, that leads to a buffer overflow, with a risk of information disclosure or remote code execution.

Vulnerabilities.Title: Heap-buffer-overflow in tiff2pdf
Vulnerabilities.Description: A heap-buffer overflow exists in LibTIFF version 4.4.0 and earlier in the function LZWEncode() inside the file tif_lzw.c, which allows an attacker who can pass a crafted TIFF file to a function like tiff2pdf to cause a denial of service or potentially code execution.

Vulnerabilities.Title: Improper Minimization of Multiple Base64-Decoded Inputs
Vulnerabilities.Description: The package minimist before 1.2.6 is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution via file index.js, function setKey() which allows adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype.
